channel.title: Factors on Tales of R - Rmarkdown Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Factors on Tales of R - Rmarkdown Blog

item.title: ...start using R, from scratch!
item.description: Some time ago, since I was able to use R by myself, have found some fellows and other people who wanted to learn R as well. Then I pointed them to help pages, to CRAN repositories‚Ä¶ but in some cases they said that didn‚Äôt know how to start using those resources. Obviously, the main self-perceived limitation for non-programmers is the use of ‚Äúcommands‚Äù -ok, many of the 80‚Äôs kids will remember the use of some command lines to access games such as PacMan, Frogger‚Ä¶ üôÇ

item.title: heatmaps with p-values (2)... coloured according to odds ratio
item.description: I like heatplots with p-values -or frequencies, or whatever-. Not very conclusive, but pretty anyway. And when talking about graphs, pretty will make our neurons to fire in more interesting ways: neurons like ‚Äúpretty‚Äù graphs. Moreover, observing your data can be as important as analysing it. It‚Äôs better to observe, to listen your patients than making tests without knowing very much about them‚Ä¶ In the heatmaps of the previous post, not a lot of information can be included.

item.title: ... ridiculously photogenic factors (heatmap with p-values)
item.description: Some months ago, I had to explore a vast amount of categorical variables before making some multivariate analyses. One good way to know your raw data, to make new hypotheses‚Ä¶etc, is to calculate some pairwise ‚Äúcrude‚Äù chi-square tests of independence of your factors, but it can be very time-consuming. I mean, not time-consuming to make the tests (with a simple command it can be done), but to revise all of them.
